Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 43503 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
Monitoring Finance, Food, and Fuel Markets for 
Development 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration 
  RSDD  –  Regional and Sustainable Development Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance

markets)

Vice-President  U. Schäfer-Preuss, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Chief Economist  J. W. Lee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
   
Team leader  D. Brooks, Principal Economist, ERD 
Team members  S. Jha, Senior Economist, ERD 
  E. San Andres, Economics Officer, ERD 
  L. Sumulong, Senior Economics Officer, ERD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The ongoing global financial crisis and the steep commodity price rise that hit markets in 
early  to  mid-2008  have  adversely  affected  the  economic  performance  and  prospects  of 
developing Asia. According to the Asian Development Outlook 2009, the regional slowdown is 
threatening to increase the number of the absolute poor—those who live on $1.25 or less 
a day—by more than 60 million people in 2009.1 In addition, high commodity prices can push 
millions more in the region back below the poverty line. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
estimates that a 30% increase in food prices will raise the number of the poor by 9 million in the 
Philippines and 22 million in Pakistan.2 This is because food composes at least 60% of the 
consumption basket of the poorest segment of the region’s population. Rising global commodity 
prices also threaten macroeconomic stability through spiraling inflation, greater fiscal burden of 
subsidies, and possible exchange rate depreciation in commodity-importing countries. 
2.  The impact of the current turmoil on ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) has 
created high demand for ADB’s services—both financial services and knowledge products. ADB 
plans to increase its lending by more than $10 billion in 2009–2010 is meant to address this 
demand at least in part. ADB’s assessments of the global economic environment and views on 
the  region’s  prospects  are  also  being  sought  more  and  more  often  by  borrowing  country 
authorities and other development partners. ADB requires more up-to-date information and 
economic  analysis  to  provide  such  assessments.  Moreover,  the  requests  go  beyond  the 
regional outlook to include ADB’s views on global economic prospects and forecasts of key 
financial, energy, and commodity market movements. With ADB establishing a reputation as a 
knowledge institution, such requests for analysis are likely to continue beyond the horizon of the 
current crisis. The Economics and Research Department (ERD) needs to step up its research 
and analysis to answer the heightened demand for knowledge products and services. 
3.  This research and development technical assistance (TA) project will seek to monitor 
financial, fuel, and food markets and study the implications of volatilities in these markets for the 
macroeconomic and social development of the DMCs. It will undertake extensive research 
based on high-frequency data of commodity and financial markets to improve understanding of 
the underpinnings of such markets and of the factors influencing the volatility of prices. It will 
analyze past and current trends, and use robust econometric models to predict the future 
movements in these markets. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Finance, food, and fuel crises. Before the global financial crisis began in 2008, the 
world economy had to deal with the difficulties brought about by a spike in fuel and food prices. 
Crude oil prices reached their peak of $147 per barrel in July 2008, at the height of the 
commodity  price crisis, while wheat, maize, soybeans, and rice prices more than doubled 
between 2006 and 2008. International commodity price levels have not returned to pre-2007 
levels, and falling currencies in some countries are giving rise to a new round of price increases. 
The food and fuel crisis may not be over and there are indications that prices could again rise 
sharply  in  2010.  In  addition,  natural  disasters  such  as  droughts,  floods,  typhoons,  and 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2009. Asian Development Outlook 2009. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2008. Food Prices and Inflation in Developing Asia: Is Poverty Reduction Coming to an End? Special report. 
Manila. 
3  The TA project first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 24 November 2009.

2   
earthquakes cause supply-side shocks that can lead to food and fuel price increases. Aside 
from their inflationary effects, spiraling fuel and commodity prices can delay general economic 
development and hamper efforts to reduce poverty. Furthermore, a crisis that affects people’s 
ability to meet their basic needs is a serious threat to social cohesion and can lead to riots and 
political instability, as has been seen in diverse places such as Egypt and Haiti. The global 
financial crisis helped ease some of the inflationary pressures by reducing the demand for 
goods, but it continued to hamper development and poverty reduction by stifling the DMCs’ 
ability to ensure continued economic growth.  
5.  Sustainable growth. Some of the important reasons behind the food and fuel crisis of 
the late 2000s are supply-side constraints. In particular, the prices of petroleum, wheat, maize, 
and rice skyrocketed partly because of concerns about the sufficiency of future supply and 
about supply continuing to outstrip demand. What is more, climate change and global warming 
are thought to cause more and stronger typhoons, desertification, and seawater inundation, 
leading to loss of agricultural production and damage to crops and infrastructure. Measures to 
improve food security and promote wider use of renewable energy sources thus need to be 
prioritized. In the short term, addressing these concerns requires a thorough analysis of the 
supply  chain  and  logistics  to  determine  whether  prices  reflect  the  relative  scarcity  of  the 
commodity and to discourage price speculation. In the long term, the sustainability of fuel and 
food markets will need to be addressed, and prices may need to reflect the cost of investments 
in sustainable energy sources and food technology. 
6.  Social protection and aid. In response to the crisis in finance, food, and fuel markets, 
governments  in  many  countries—both  developed  and  developing—have  instituted  social 
protection measures.  From  price  controls  in  the  Russian  Federation  to  unconditional  cash 
transfers in the Philippines and export bans in India, such social protection measures are often 
costly and distort the allocation of resources. As such, effective monitoring of the crisis is an 
essential tool for policy makers to determine if and when social protection measures may be 
eased out. Likewise, donor countries need such information to determine how much and what 
type of aid is needed by severely affected countries, and for how long. 
7.  Regional  cooperation  and  integration. Understanding the underpinnings of global 
financial and commodity markets can facilitate cooperation by exploiting differences between 
regional economies. Take, for example, the financial market. The regional economies are in 
varying  degrees  of  financial  market  development.  Encouraging  cooperation  among  these 
economies can facilitate the use of savings from surplus economies as investment in deficit 
economies. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  The Technical Assistance Strategic Forum 2008 identified major areas for research 
through ADB’s research and development technical assistance program. For 2009–2011, the 
five strategic priorities for research are (i) promoting inclusive growth, (ii) addressing climate 
change  for  sustainable  development,  (iii) facilitating  knowledge  for  regional  integration, 
(iv) providing support to address the continuing increase in commodity prices, and (v) assessing 
and responding to demographic change. This TA project will squarely address priorities (iii) and 
(iv) of the forum by generating interregional knowledge products and monitoring prices in the 
financial,  energy,  and  commodity  markets.  It  will  also  deal  with  sustainable  development 
concerns by looking at the climate change issues and natural disasters that cause supply-side

3
shocks and thereby affect prices. High-frequency data with market trend analysis can have 
implications for social protection policies and aid exit strategies. 
9.  This TA project will help ADB develop its own capacity for research on finance, food, and 
fuel markets. While the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank both release regular 
updates on commodity prices, these are available only monthly. More frequent price monitoring 
will keep ADB researchers abreast of market developments that may affect DMC policy and 
economic growth. 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  effective  policy  development  based  on  extensive 
research on finance, food, and fuel markets. Information is an essential input in policy-making 
especially in the presence of market volatility and uncertainty. Governments need timely and 
accurate information coupled with rigorous analysis in order to know the current situation, adjust 
expectations, and form policies to adjust to ever-changing realities. The project, by providing 
DMCs  with  this  information  and  analysis,  will  strengthen  the  links  between  research  and 
policy-making and help raise the reputation of ADB as a producer of knowledge outputs not only 
related to Asia but related to the global economy as well.  
11.  The  project’s  expected  outcome  will  be  an  improved  understanding  of  the 
macroeconomic and social impact of rising and volatile commodity prices and financial market 
uncertainties, and of the trends and issues underlying these markets. Knowing more about the 
market underpinnings of various commodities will equip ADB to provide better policy advice to 
its DMCs in terms of adapting to and mitigating the impact of commodity price volatilities, while 
thorough analysis of the financial markets can help ADB member countries institute proper 
measures to prepare for or even prevent another financial crisis. Moreover, the project will shed 
light on the macroeconomic and social impact of natural disasters and other supply shocks as 
they affect the prices of basic necessities and constrain access to credit. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The project will identify key financial market indicators and commodities in the global 
economy, especially those that are of particular relevance to ADB’s DMCs. Commodities that 
are heavily traded by ADB’s DMCs will be included in the project. Key economic developments 
in  selected  industrial  countries  will  also  be  regularly  assessed:  in  particular,  economic 
developments in the United States, the eurozone, and Japan will be closely watched, as these 
countries are all relatively important for ADB’s DMCs. These are also the economies that 
provide  context  in  ERD’s  annual  flagship  publication,  the  Asian  Development  Outlook. 
Moreover, the project will analyze the interactions between financial and commodities markets, 
on one hand, and inflation, monetary and fiscal policies, and balance of payments on the other. 
Emphasis will be given to the impact of external shocks such as financial and economic crises 
and natural disasters on the availability of credit and the prices of commodities. Data to be 
gathered through the TA project will help develop ADB’s capacity to conduct in-depth research 
into these markets and quickly respond to DMCs’ information needs in the event of market 
shocks.  
13.  A technical workshop and a conference on these markets are proposed under this 
project.  The  technical  workshop,  to  which  high-caliber  resource  persons,  economists,  and 
statisticians will be invited, will define the research problems to be tackled, the specific prices

4   
and market indicators to be monitored, the analytical framework to be used, and the study 
methodology to be applied by the project. The conference, on the other hand, will include 
representatives from government, the private sector, academe, and multilateral organizations. It 
will take stock of the lessons and policies learned from the project, evaluate its performance, 
and chart the way forward.  
14.  Analytical papers using the data that will be gathered are expected to be generated. 
They  can  be  published  as  working  papers,  journal  articles,  or  policy  briefs.  Rigorous 
econometric methods and statistical techniques will be used in analyzing the data. Periodic 
price indicator bulletins will be prepared for the financial markets and commodities covered by 
this  project.  Initially,  the  list  of  indicators  may  include  interest  rates,  credit  default  swaps, 
sovereign risk spreads, and prices of crude oil, natural gas, rice, wheat, maize, soybeans, 
vegetable oils, sugar, and rubber. Relevant price benchmarks for these commodities will be 
selected from data available from ADB’s current data subscriptions. In addition, a shipping price 
benchmark, reflecting demand for bulk commodities, will be monitored.  
15.  The high-frequency data and analysis on the finance, food, and fuel markets will be 
made available to ADB staff, researchers, and policy makers through a one-stop website that 
will be managed by ERD in cooperation with the Department of External Relations and the 
Office of Information Systems and Technology. In parallel with the implementation of the TA 
project, mechanisms will be put in place within the Office of the Chief Economist to ensure the 
sustainability  of  these  monitoring  activities  beyond  the  life  of  the  TA  project.  Information 
collected under this TA will be used as inputs for possible Management briefings on issues 
related to the global economy. 
16.  The project will also publish periodic bulletins on financial markets indicators and food 
and fuel prices. The bulletins will contain summaries of the latest data available as well as 
trends analysis based on econometric models to be developed by the sector economists. They 
will be published on the project website and e-mailed to subscribers, who will include ADB staff 
and interested researchers. The frequency of these bulletins will be based on the availability of 
quality and disaggregated data. 
17.  In summary, the key outputs of the project will be (i) periodic financial, energy, and 
commodity  price  monitors;  (ii) regular  macroeconomic  updates  on  industrial  countries; 
(iii) publications such as policy briefs and working papers; and (iv) a webpage that will house the 
information  generated  by  the  project.  These  outputs  are  all  designed  to  give  ADB  staff, 
researchers, and policy makers the most up-to-date information on the finance, fuel, and food 
markets and robust analysis of these data that is easily accessible and convenient. The project 
activities will be overseen by ERD.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). Details of the cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA project, which will be managed by ERD. 
The project is expected to be carried over 24 months, from January 2010 to December 2011.

5
The project will use technical inputs from ERD’s three divisions. Given the broad scope of the 
project, ranging from macroeconomic impact to social protection policies, and the breadth of the 
data  required,  the  project  team  will  also  work  intensively  with  ADB’s  other  knowledge 
departments—i.e., the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) and the Regional and 
Sustainable  Development  Department  (RSDD)—and  regional  departments.  While  OREI  is 
currently monitoring commodity prices, interest rates, and bond spreads, the monitoring is 
limited  to  a  small  number  of  commodities,  and  to  selected  economies  in  East  Asia  and 
Southeast  Asia.  This  TA  project  will  attempt  to  expand  the  coverage  of  countries  and 
commodities, as well as broaden the scope of analysis in these markets. To maximize synergies 
and avoid duplication of efforts, the project team will work closely with OREI. For issues related 
to food security and renewable energy, ERD will coordinate with RSDD. In general, all outputs 
will be subject to interdepartmental review and to external review during the workshops or 
conference. 
20.  The  TA  project  will  require  6  person-months  of  international  consulting  services, 
54 person-months  of  national  consulting  services,  and  1.5  person-months  of  international 
resource persons’ services. National consultants will be citizens of the Philippines who will be 
based at ADB headquarters in Manila. The consultants, to be hired as individual consultants, 
will comprise sector economists, sector research analysts, and a project manager. ADB will hire 
these consultants according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). ERD will provide coordination and administrative support. The terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. Disbursements under the TA will conform to 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook4. 
21.  The three sector economists—one each for the finance, food, and fuel markets—will 
design the research methodology, econometric models, and analytical templates that will be 
used in analyzing the data to be gathered under the project. They will also assist and train ADB 
staff and the sector research analysts in using the analytical tools and knowledge that will be 
generated during the TA project. 
22.  The three sector research analysts—one each for the finance, food, and fuel markets—
will seek and gather data on these markets from all available resources, enter them into the 
project  database,  and  do  data  analysis  based  on  the  templates  designed  by  the  sector 
economists. A project manager will be hired to facilitate the implementation of the TA and 
manage  the  project  website  in  cooperation  with  the  Office  of  Information  Systems  and 
Technology. Resource persons will provide inputs to the work of the consultants, write detailed 
comments on TA outputs, and serve as discussants during workshops and conferences. 
23.  Reports will be drafted by the project team and the international consultants. Periodic 
bulletins on the finance, food, and fuel markets will be generated by the project team using data 
and analysis provided by the sector research analysts and will be posted on the project website.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Monitoring Finance, Food, and Fuel Markets for Development, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Sector Economists (3 international, 6 person-months) 
1.  Under the supervision of the project team leader, three sector economists (one each for 
financial markets, energy markets, and commodities markets) will be hired for 2 months each to 
develop analytical frameworks, economic models, and a list of indicators for high-frequency 
monitoring. They will design the research methodology that will be applied by the research team 
in the Asian Development Bank (ADB). They will be hired intermittently generally from their 
home base, but they will be expected to attend the scheduled project conference and workshop. 
They will write at least one paper using the data gathered by the project. The consultants will 
(i)  draft the research methodology and analytical framework for the sector; 
(ii)  determine  the  set  of  high-frequency  data  and  indicators  that  need  to  be 
monitored by the research team;  
(iii)  design an analytical template for the daily, weekly, or monthly price indicator that 
will be disseminated by ADB; 
(iv)  participate  in  and  give  presentations  during  the  technical  workshop  and 
conference to be organized under the project; 
(v)  write and publish at least one paper using the data gathered under this project; 
and 
(vi)  provide comments and inputs as required. 
2.  Resource Persons (10 international, 1.5 person-months) 
2.  Under the supervision of the project team leader, 10 resource persons will be hired to 
participate  in  the  workshop  and  conference.  The  resource  persons  should  have  (i) expert 
knowledge of the sector and of development issues in Asia, and (ii) extensive experience in 
applied economic research and development policy. 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  Sector Research Analysts (3 national, 36 person-months) 
3.  Under the supervision of the project team leader, three sector research analysts (one 
each  for  financial  markets,  energy  markets,  and  commodities  markets)  will  be  hired  for 
12 months each to gather data daily; draft daily, weekly, and monthly price indicator bulletins 
using a template designed by the sector economists; and provide analytical inputs as required. 
The consultants will be hired to work full time at ADB headquarters. The consultants will 
(i)  gather data daily, according to the source, type, and frequency requirements set 
by the project team leader and the sector economist; 
(ii)  draft  daily,  weekly,  or  monthly  price  indicator  bulletins  using  the  template 
designed by the sector economist; 
(iii)  provide research assistance to the project team leader and the sector economist 
as required; and

Appendix 3  11 
(iv)  write papers, provide analytical input, and review papers of other team members 
as required. 
  2.  Project Manager (1 national, 18 person-months) 
4.  Under the supervision of the project team leader, the consultant will handle logistical 
coordination for the project and update the project website daily. The consultant shall be hired to 
work full time for 18 months at ADB headquarters. The consultant will 
(i)  provide overall coordination and logistical support for the project; 
(ii)  help conceptualize and design the project website; 
(iii)  upload daily, weekly, or monthly price indicator bulletins after editing by the 
project team leader; 
(iv)  help organize the technical conferences to be conducted under the project; 
(v)  help organize seminars to be conducted under the project as required; and 
(vi)  assist the project team leader in the overall management of the project.
